title: HOMEMADE GUNS
historical_context: This article reflects the counterculture and DIY ethos of the 1970s, where individuals sought to create their own tools and weapons outside of conventional means.
target_audience: Hobbyists, survivalists, and those interested in DIY weaponry.
short_summary: The article provides detailed instructions on how to construct homemade firearms, commonly referred to as 'zip guns', using readily available materials. It discusses various designs and safety precautions for testing these makeshift weapons.
summary: In 'HOMEMADE GUNS', Kurt Saxon delves into the construction of zip guns, a type of improvised firearm made primarily from pipes and other common materials. The article outlines the basic design, which includes a wooden stock, a pipe barrel, and a simple trigger mechanism made from galvanized tin. Saxon emphasizes the ease of assembly, noting that these guns can accommodate various calibers, from .22 to .45, and even larger cartridges with the right modifications. He provides a step-by-step guide on how to create these weapons, including safety measures for testing their functionality before actual use. The instructions highlight the resourcefulness of individuals in creating their own firearms, reflecting a broader cultural trend of self-sufficiency and rebellion against conventional norms during the era. Saxon also warns readers about the legal implications of creating such devices, advising against registration to avoid legal repercussions.
